title: 113_hr4510
content: The "Insurance Capital Standards Clarification Act of 2014" clarifies the application of leverage and risk-based capital requirements. The Dodd-Frank Act (12 U.S.C. 5371) is amended to define terms related to the business of insurance and regulated foreign subsidiaries and affiliates. The Dodd-Frank Act is amended to define terms related to the business of insurance and regulated foreign subsidiaries and affiliates, including criteria for determining comparable foreign insurance regulatory authority. The term 'capacity as a regulated insurance entity' includes actions related to insurance provision by entities regulated by state insurance regulators or foreign agencies, excluding unregulated financial activities. The new subsection clarifies that in establishing capital requirements for depository institution holding companies or nonbank financial companies, federal banking agencies are not required to include persons regulated by state insurance authorities. The new subsection clarifies that federal banking agencies are not obligated to include persons regulated by state insurance authorities in setting capital requirements for depository institution holding companies or nonbank financial companies. This subsection does not limit the Board of Governors' authority to issue regulations on capital requirements for these entities. Institutions supervised by the Federal Reserve and regulated by State insurance authorities or foreign subsidiaries are not required to prepare financial statements according to Generally Accepted Accounting Principles.
